docs.lead_paragraph: The campaign debate over prescription drugs for the elderly has become a confusing muddle of partisan charges and countercharges, with both sides invoking the standard bogymen of health care debates, from ''big government'' to ''H.M.O. bureaucrats.'' But a few things are clear, health analysts say.

headline.main: BASIC DIFFERENCES IN RIVAL PROPOSALS ON DRUG COVERAGE

docs.abstract: Campaign debate over prescription drugs for elderly has become confusing muddle of partisan charges and countercharges; health analysts say approaches of two presidential candidates are so different, and there are so many unknowns about Gov Geroge W Bush's plan, that it would be very difficult for average Medicare beneficiary to compare Bush and Gore plans and determine how much he would pay in premiums and co-payments and how much he would receive in benefits; given what is known, many analysts and consumer advocates consider Vice Pres Al Gore's plan to be more generous; experts note that none of drug benefits being proposed for Medicare are as generous as what many working people routinely receive; chart with major components of each candidate's plan (L)
docs.snippet: The campaign debate over prescription drugs for the elderly has become a confusing muddle of partisan charges and countercharges, with both sides invoking the standard bogymen of health care debates, from ''big government'' to ''H.M.O. bureaucrats.''...

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR the last 20 years, the region's jazz fans have faithfully circled the dates on their calendars: the second Sunday of each month from September through April. The can't-miss-it attraction? Concerts presented by the Presbyterian Jazz Society in the parish hall of the landmark First Presbyterian Church on Lincoln Avenue in Mount Vernon.

headline.main: Sundays of Bluesy Jazz And Food

docs.abstract: Article on Presbyterian Jazz Society jazz concerts, on second Sunday of each month from September through April, at First Presbyterian Church in Mount Vernon, NY; photo (Special Issue: Entertainment) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Adult children are often expected to care for aging parents who become frail or ill, but a new survey has found that many may not be completely prepared for the task. In the survey, conducted by Family Circle magazine and the Kaiser Family Foundation, 43 percent of the respondents said they knew little or nothing about their parents' health insurance, and 45 percent did not even know who their doctors were. Almost one-third said they were unaware of where their parents kept financial statements and other important documents like health insurance cards.

headline.main: Ready, or Often Not, To Provide Elder Care

docs.abstract: Survey conducted by Family Circle magazine and Kaiser Family Foundation suggests that 43 percent of adult children know little or nothing about their parents' health insurance and that 45 percent do not even know who their parents' doctors are (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: JENNA died two weeks ago, so the thoughts of her parents, Theresa and Bruce Gudin, are not as preoccupied by their insurance carrier as they once were. But their struggle to get coverage for home health care for Jenna, their daughter who suffered from spinal muscular atrophy and died at the age of 13 months, underscores the difficulties that can arise when anything in an insurance contract isn't crystal clear.
docs.abstract: Jennifer Steinhauer Money & Medicine column on understanding intricacies of health insurance policies; focuses on problems Theresa and Bruce Gudin encountered when trying to get home health care for their daughter on policy they had with Horizon Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Brian Schweitzer, a peppermint, alfalfa and cattle farmer running for the Senate in Montana, holds up a pair of pill bottles for the camera and declares, ''I bet you'd be surprised to find out that veterinarians prescribe the exact same medicine for dogs, and charge half as much.'' In a New Hampshire television commercial, Gov. Jeanne Shaheen, seeking re-election, has found a novel way to attack her Republican opponent, former Senator Gordon Humphrey: she says his vote against creating a prescription drug benefit under Medicare makes him ''an extremist.''

headline.main: Costly Prescriptions: One Issue That Fits All

docs.abstract: Rising cost of medication is major campaign theme of candidates around nation in 2000 elections; topic has become such ubiquitous feature of this year's advertising that it is virtually requirement for candidates to have prescription drug commercial; candidates of every stripe, and running for variety of offices, all seek to sound like friends of little guy in his fight against escalating drug costs; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WELCOME to Newark International Airport from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, transmitting on highway advisory radio 530-AM. Please be advised that monorail service has been suspended at all stations and that despite the exhaustive guidance I'm about to give you in this radio announcement, coming here today may turn out to be the biggest mistake you have ever made. We sincerely regret any inconvenience. A $3.8 billion construction program is under way at the airport. Over the next two years we will improve the roads, build two parking garages and expand and upgrade the terminals. The thing is, just about the time we're completing that work, we'll announce another construction program that is even more expensive and disruptive. Hey, it's not just us; in case you haven't noticed, every airport in the country is in a constant state of construction and rebuilding. It's a little something we do on the theory that if we keep you busy dodging bulldozers and looking for parking spaces, you won't notice all the flight delays, flight overbookings, flight reroutings and flight cancellations. We abjectly apologize for any inconvenience.

headline.main: Park and Ride And Ride and Ride and . . .

docs.abstract: Neil Genzlinger Jersey column offers his take on $3.8 billion, two-year renovation and expansion project at Newark International Airport; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton took office promising health insurance for all Americans, so he was distressed by the steady increase in the number of uninsured from 1993 to 1998. But finally the trend has been reversed. The Census Bureau reported that the number of people without insurance dropped last year by 1.7 million, to 42.6 million. The number of people with employment-based insurance rose 3.4 million, to 172 million. Robert Pear

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A Sept. 24 editorial was correct to say we should use part of the budget surplus to ensure every American has quality health care -- and there is a bill before Congress to do just that.
docs.abstract: Letter by Sen Paul Wellsteon and service employees union president Andrew L Stern endorses Health Security for All Americans Act (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    A Sept. 24 editorial was correct to say we should use part of the budget surplus to ensure every American has quality health care -- and there is a bill before Congress to do just that.

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City's rebounding economy has produced a record number of jobs, but a new study shows that the number of low-wage jobs, those paying less than $25,000 a year, is growing much faster than the number of middle- or high-wage jobs. The study, to be released tomorrow, found that while the city had added thousands of high-paying Wall Street and Silicon Alley jobs in recent years, the fastest job growth had been among low-wage service employees, like restaurant workers, security guards, day care workers and home attendants for the elderly.

headline.main: Low-Wage Jobs Leading Gains In Employment

docs.abstract: Number of low-wage jobs, paying less than $25,000 a year, is growing much faster than number of middle- or high-wage jobs in New York City's rebounding economy; study, conducted by team of economists from government agencies and nonprofit groups, finds number of low-paying jobs has climbed 22 percent, nearly four times as much as jobs paying more than $75,000; notes that pay for low-wage service employees, like restaurant workers, security guards, day care workers and home attendants for elderly do not pay enough to support family; finds that median wage for city's low-wage workers actually dropped by 2 percent from 1989 to 1999, after taking inflation into account; study fucuses on largely overlooked cracks in city's economic boom; photos; graph (M)
docs.snippet: New York City's rebounding economy has produced a record number of jobs, but a new study shows that the number of low-wage jobs, those paying less than $25,000 a year, is growing much faster than the number of middle- or high-wage jobs.    The study,...

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was tempting. Six cities in 12 days, unpacking only once? Add two days in London and it was even more inviting. Especially since this tour-cruise to four Scandinavian capitals, St. Petersburg and an optional side trip to Berlin was for ''experienced travelers.'' Make that ''mature,'' the brochure amended, using an adjective that describes me better than ''experienced.'' Although I had never before been on a cruise -- unless two nights aboard an informal small ship gliding along Glacier Bay in Alaska qualifies -- or vacationed on an organized tour, this Grand Circle Travel trip with 12 days aboard the Norwegian Cruise Line's Norwegian Dream looked too good to pass up.
docs.abstract: Barbara Delatiner travel article describes 12-day cruise for seniors, mostly retired professional couples, to four Scandinavian capitals, aboard Norwegian Cruise Line's Norwegian Dream; photos; map (M)
